lg.l: HARLEY the Nation's great Support,
Returning home one day from Court,
(His Mind with publick cares possest,
All Europe's Busness in his breast,)
Observ'd a Parson near White Hall,
Cheap'ning old Authors on a stall.
The Priest was pretty well in case,
And shew'd some Humour in his face;
Look'd with an easy careless mien,
A perfect stranger to the spleen;
Of size that might a Pulpit fill,
But more inclining to sit still.My Lord who (if a Man may say't)
Loves mischief better than his meat,)
Was now dispos'd to crack a Jest;
And bid friend Lewis go in quest,
(This Lewis is a cunning shaver,
And very much in Harley's favour)
Jn quest, who might this parson be,
What was his name of what degree;
If Possible to learn his story,
And Whether he was whig or Tory?
Lewis his patrons humour knows;
Away upon his errand goes,
And quickly did the matter sift,
Found out That it was doctor S───t:
A clergyman of special note,
For hunning those of his own coat;
Which made his Brethren of the gown
Take care by·times to run him down:
No Libertine nor over-nice,
Addicted to no sort of vice;
Went where he pleas'd, said what he thought,
Not rich but ow'd no man a groat;
In state opinoions a-la-mode,
He hated Wharton like a toad;
Had giv'n the Faction many a wound,
And libell'd all the Junta round;
Kept company with men of wit,
Who often father'd what he writ;
His works were hawk'd in ev'ry street,
But seldom rose above a sheet:
Of late indeed the Paper stamp:
Did very much his Genius cramp,
And since he could not spend his fire,
He now intended to retire.
Said Harley J desire to know
From his own mouth if this be so?
step to the doctor straigt & say,
I'd have him dine with me to day.
S───t seem'd to wonder what he meant,
Nor wou'd believe My Lord had sent;
So never offer'd once to stir,
But coldly said, your servant, sir.
Does he refuse me? Harly cry'd:
He does, with Jnsolence & pride.
some few days after Harley spies
The doctor fastn'd by the eyes,
At chairing cross, among the Rout,
Where Painted Monsters are hung out.
He b·pull'd the string & stopt his Coach,
Beck'ning the Doctor to approach.
S────t who could neither fly nor hide,
Came sneaking to the Chariot-side,
And offer'd many a lame excuse;
He never meant the least Abuse────
My Lord────the Honour you design'd────
extremely proud────but I had din'd────
J'm sure J never shou'd neglect────
No Man alive has more respect────
Well, J shall think of that no more,
If you'll be sure to come at four.
The doctor now obeys the summons,
Likes both his Company & commons;
Displays his talant setts till ten,
Next day invited, comes again,
Soon grows domestick, seldom fails
Either at morning, or at meals;
Came early, & departed late:
Jn short, the Gudgeon took the bait:My Lord wou'd carry on the jest,
And down to Windsor takes his guest.
S────t much admires the place & air,
And longs to be a Canon there;
In summer round the Park to ride,
In winter────never to reside.
A Canon! that's a place too mean:
No, Doctor, you shall be a Dean;
Two dozen Canons round your stall,
And you the Tyrent ore them all:
You need but cross the Jrish seas,
To live in plenty, power & ease.
Poor s──t departs, & what is worse,
With borrow'd money in his purse;
Travels at least a hundred leagues,
And suffers numberless fatigues.
suppose him, now a Dean compleat,
Deuoutly lolling in his seat;
The silver Virge, with decent pride,
Stuck underneath his cushion-side.
suppose him gone through all vexations,
Patents, Jnstalments, Abjurations,
First fruits & tenths, and Chapter treats,
Dues, payments, fees, Demands, and cheats,
(Yẹ wicked Laity's contriving,
To hinder Clergy men from thriving;)
Now all the Doctor's money's spent,
His tenants wrong him in his rent;
The farmers, spightfully combin'd
Force him to take his tithes in kind;
And Parvisol 1The Deans agent a french man discounts arrears,
By bills for Taxes and Repairs.
Poor s────t with all his losses vext,
Not knowing Where to turn him next;
Above a thousand pounds in debt,
Takes Horse & in a mighty fret
Rides day & night at such a rate,
He soon arrives at Harley's gate
But was so Dirty, pale, & thin,
Old Read would hardly let him in.
Said Harley, welcome Rev'rend Dean!
What makes your worship look so lean?
Why sure you won't appear in town,
Jn that old Wig & rusty gown!
J doubt your heart is set on pelf
so much that you neglect yourself,
What! J suppose now stocks are high,
You've some good purchase in your;
Or is your money out at use?────
Truce, my good Lord, J beg a truce!
The Docter in a passion cry'd;
Your raillery is misapply'd:
J have Experience dearly bought,
You know J am not worth a groat:
But you resolv'd to have your jest,
And 'twas a folly to contest:
And since you now have done your worst,
Pray, leave me where you found me first.170-904A
